DataElement.definition: A short-form abbreviation for a particular gene assigned by the HGNC (HUGO Gene Nomenclature Committee - an organism specific nomenclature committee).

DataElementConcept.definition: A functional unit of heredity which occupies a specific position on a particular chromosome and serves as the template for a product that contributes to a phenotype or a biological function.:An instance of something happening, such as an event or incident.
DataElementConcept.administrativeNotes: 2/6/23 released/standard per Smita/DSS. jk;  1/27/23 Upd per CRDC DSS. mr; 9/19/22 created for CRDC DSS CRDC Data Standards. jk

ObjectClass.definition: A functional unit of heredity which occupies a specific position (locus) on a particular chromosome, is capable of reproducing itself exactly at each cell division, and directs the formation of a protein or other product. The gene as a functional unit consists of a discrete segment of a giant DNA molecule containing the purine (adenine and guanine) and pyrimidine (cytosine and thymine) bases in the ordered and correct sequence that encodes a specific functional product (i.e., a protein or RNA molecule).

Concepts.definition: A functional unit of heredity which occupies a specific position on a particular chromosome and serves as the template for a product that contributes to a phenotype or a biological function.

Property.definition: Occurrence; an instance of something happening.

Concepts.definition: An instance of something happening, such as an event or incident.

ConceptualDomain.definition: A functional unit of heredity which occupies a specific position (locus) on a particular chromosome, is capable of reproducing itself exactly at each cell division, and directs the formation of a protein or other product. The gene as a functional unit consists of a discrete segment of a giant DNA molecule containing the purine (adenine and guanine) and pyrimidine (cytosine and thymine) bases in the ordered and correct sequence that encodes a specific functional product (i.e., a protein or RNA molecule).

ValueDomain.definition: The worldwide authority that assigns standardized nomenclature to human genes. The HUGO Gene Nomenclature Committee is responsible for approving unique symbols and names for human loci, including protein coding genes, ncRNA genes, and pseudogenes, to allow unambiguous scientific communication. It is jointly funded by the US National Human Genome Research Institute (NHGRI) and Wellcome (UK) and operates under the auspices of the Human Genome Organization (HUGO)._An arbitrary sign (written or printed) that has acquired a conventional significance._The words or language units by which a thing is known.

ValueMeaning.definition: A curated human-specific online repository of Human Genome Organization (HUGO) Gene Nomenclature Committee (HGNC)-approved gene nomenclature, gene groups, and links to associated databases, including resources that supply genomic, proteomic, and phenotypic information.

Concepts.definition: A curated human-specific online repository of Human Genome Organization (HUGO) Gene Nomenclature Committee (HGNC)-approved gene nomenclature, gene groups, and links to associated databases, including resources that supply genomic, proteomic, and phenotypic information.

ConceptualDomain.definition: A functional unit of heredity which occupies a specific position (locus) on a particular chromosome, is capable of reproducing itself exactly at each cell division, and directs the formation of a protein or other product. The gene as a functional unit consists of a discrete segment of a giant DNA molecule containing the purine (adenine and guanine) and pyrimidine (cytosine and thymine) bases in the ordered and correct sequence that encodes a specific functional product (i.e., a protein or RNA molecule).

Concepts.definition: The words or language units by which a thing is known.
An arbitrary sign (written or printed) that has acquired a conventional significance.

The worldwide authority that assigns standardized nomenclature to human genes. The HUGO Gene Nomenclature Committee is responsible for approving unique symbols and names for human loci, including protein coding genes, ncRNA genes, and pseudogenes, to allow unambiguous scientific communication. It is jointly funded by the US National Human Genome Research Institute (NHGRI) and Wellcome (UK) and operates under the auspices of the Human Genome Organization (HUGO).
